statement.text: GSV ablation techniques (thermal: RFA, EVLA; non-thermal: cyanoacrylate glue, MOCA) have replaced stripping as first-line treatment for GSV reflux, with equivalent long-term efficacy (>90% closure at 5 years), faster recovery, and distinct advantages for specific clinical scenarios.
statement.formal: GSV_Ablation_Success: Thermal (RFA/EVLA) ≈ Non-Thermal (Glue/MOCA) ≈ 93-97% at 1 year; >90% at 5 years

explanation.intuition: Instead of surgically removing the GSV (stripping), modern ablation techniques destroy the vein in place using heat, glue, or mechanical/chemical injury. The body then absorbs the treated vein over weeks to months, achieving the same goal with less trauma and faster recovery.
explanation.key_insight: Choosing between ablation techniques depends on patient anatomy (vein size, tortuosity), clinical context (anesthesia tolerance, cost), and provider experience. Non-thermal techniques avoid tumescent anesthesia and reduce nerve injury risk, making them attractive for above-knee GSV treatment.
explanation.technical_details: Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) uses segmental heating to 120°C via a catheter, treating 7cm segments over 20 seconds. Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) uses continuous wavelength-specific energy (810-1470nm) causing irreversible vein wall damage. Cyanoacrylate adhesive (VenaSeal) polymerizes within the vein, causing occlusion and fibrosis. Mechanochemical ablation (MOCA/ClariVein) combines rotating wire endothelial injury with liquid sclerosant. All require ultrasound guidance and proper catheter positioning 2-5cm from the SFJ.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Thermal ablation is superior to non-thermal. Reality: Both have equivalent 5-year efficacy; choice depends on clinical factors.
Misconception: Tumescent anesthesia is always required. Reality: Non-thermal techniques (glue, MOCA) avoid tumescent anesthesia entirely.
Misconception: Large veins require surgery. Reality: Thermal ablation can treat veins up to 25mm with appropriate technique.

disadvantages: Higher pain, bruising with short wavelengths

diagnosis: Measure GSV diameter at multiple levels
Assess for DVT and arterial disease
treatment: Access via percutaneous needle (usually below knee)
Wire and catheter advancement to SFJ

learning_objectives: Compare mechanisms of thermal and non-thermal ablation
Select appropriate ablation technique based on clinical factors
Describe the procedural steps for each technique
Recognize complications specific to each modality
clinical_pearls: All techniques have >90% closure at 5 years - choose based on clinical factors
Non-thermal (glue, MOCA) avoids tumescent anesthesia and nerve injury
Position catheter tip 2-5cm from SFJ to avoid CFV injury
Tumescent anesthesia provides heat sink and anesthesia for thermal ablation
Immediate return to walking encouraged after all techniques
